results.title: The Art of meditation
results.creator_credit: Irving Hartley, Films For a New Age and Hartley Productions
results.brief_description: Alan Watts discusses the art of meditation as an alternative to the pressures and frustration of modern life. The film brings him right into the midst of the viewing audience who can follow along as he leads them step by step in the disciplines of body posture, breath control and concentration, toward that state of relaxation that stops “the chattering in the skull”. The film does not set forth the principles of meditation in academic fashion, it is experiential, leaving one with a feeling of peace and well-being.

results.title: The Art of it
results.brief_description: The Australian Youth Orchestra, under conductor John Hopkins, is seen at rehearsal and in a concert performance of Benjamin Britten’s ” Young Person’s Guide to the Orchestra”.

results.title: The Art of hockey umpiring
results.brief_description: A detailed examination of the rules of men’s hockey including such pre match responsibilities of the umpire as personal equipment, dress, ground markings and the extent of the playing area under is jurisdiction. An investigation into common infringements of the rules as seen in context with the game. No other credits available.

results.title: Australian Aborigines: art, life and religion
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Modern social studies”.
A portrayal of some aspects of Australian First Nations people’s ceremonial practices. The spiritual significance of body paintings, dancing and singing is explained. Taken during the University of Sydney’s expedition to Arnhem Land, led by Professor A. P. Elkin in 1952.

results.title: Art in the western world
results.creator_credit: Milan Herzog and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Treasures from the National Gallery of Art in Washington are used to present the development of Western art from the thirteenth century. The film opens with a discussion of Byzantine and early Italian painting and explains the gradual development of realism during the Renaissance. The work of famous artists such as Velasquez, Rembrandt, Van Eyck and Goya illustrate the development of art up to the nineteenth century. The film concludes with examples of French Impressionism and Post Impressionism.

results.title: Art in Australia
results.brief_description: Melbourne is an art conscious city, the centre of which is the National Gallery, housing many old masters and other works of art. The film shows the contribution to this interest in art being made by the annual Dunlop Art Contest. The film shows some of the work involved in the unpacking, cataloguing and judging of the hundreds of entries from all over Australia, and concludes with views of the 1951 winning entries with comments on each by the judges. No other credits available.

results.title: Art from found materials
results.brief_description: Many artists use ‘found materials’ with imagination. They use such natural things as seeds and shells as well as scrap materials. Both collage and assemblage are illustrated. The materials used, their organisation, and techniques for adhering offer endless possibilities for creative form and images. No other credits available.

results.title: The Art director
results.creator_credit: Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Explains the work of the art director in the production of a feature motion picture. Shows how motion picture sets are designed and constructed and indicate the research necessary to make them authentic. Suitable for Mid-Secondary and above students. No other credits available.

results.title: Art and the community
results.brief_description: This film is a Commonwealth Teleview. Sir William Emrys Williams, Secretary-General of the Arts Council of Great Britain, answers questions put to him by Rooney Pelletier on various aspects of art sponsorship, with particular reference to the encouragement of opera, the theatre, music, ballet, painting and sculpture in Britain. No other credits available.

results.title: Art and reality: the Renaissance
results.creator_credit: John Warner, John Seabourne, Educational Foundation for Visual Aids and Seabourne Enterprises
results.brief_description: This film illustrates the fundamental change form Byzantine symbolism to Renaissance humanism. A simple but comprehensive study is made of composition and perspective, the visual aspects of painting and on attitudes inspired by early Renaissance humanism. Suitable for Lower-Upper Secondary students.
